revision.text:
[[File:Judith Auer (1905-1944).jpg|thumb|Judith Auer]] '''Judith Auer''' (née '''Vallentin''') (19 September 1905 – 27 October 1944) was a [[Widerstand|resistance]] fighter against the [[Nazism|Nazi]] régime in [[Germany]].
==Early life== Auer was born in [[Zürich]]. Her father was the communist writer, Erich Vallentin.<ref name="gdw">[http://www.gdw-berlin.de/bio/ausgabe_mit-e.php?id=400 Short biography of Judith Auer] German Resistance Memorial Center, Berlin. Retrieved May 18, 2010</ref> After her parents' untimely death in 1917,<ref name="bda-koep">[http://www.bda-koepenick.de/verfolgte/Judith%20Auer Judith Auer] Vereinigung der Verfolgten des Naziregimes - Bund der Antifaschisten [[Köpenick]], Germany. Retrieved July 29, 2010 {{de icon}}</ref> Judith was brought up by a well-to-do [[Jew]]ish family.<ref name="bda-koep" /> She completed her ''[[Abitur]]'' and began studies in [[music]] in the hopes of becoming a [[pianist]].<ref name="bda-koep" />
In 1924, as a student, she joined the [[Young Communist League of Germany]],<ref name="gdw" /> and the next year, moved to Berlin. There, she met and married [[Erich Auer]], a functionary in the [[Communist Party of Germany]] (KPD), in 1926.<ref name="bda-koep" /> In 1927, she joined the KPD. In 1928, Auer went to [[Moscow]] with her husband and worked at the [[Comintern]]'s offices.
In 1929, her daughter Ruth was born.<ref name="bda-koep" /> To earn money, Auer learned [[typing]] and [[shorthand]] and took a job at a KPD establishment.
==Resistance activities== After [[Hitler]] [[Machtergreifung|seized power]] in Germany in 1933 and the KPD was banned by the new régime, Auer eventually found herself working for [[AEG]] at the Kabelwerk [[Oberspree]] ("cable works"),<ref name="gdw" /> first as a shorthand typist, and later as a buying agent.<ref name="bda-koep" /> It was here that Auer first came into contact with the resistance group around [[Fritz Plön]],<ref name="bda-koep" /> a [[welding|welder]], who himself had contacts with the resistance group around [[Anton Saefkow]], [[Franz Jacob (Resistance fighter)|Franz Jacob]], [[Bernhard Bästlein]] and [[Karl Klodt]], the [[Saefkow-Jacob-Bästlein Organization]].<ref name="gdw" /> Auer also had had a long friendship with Änne Weiß, who became Saefkow's wife.<ref name="bda-koep" />
Auer managed her resistance group's finances and used business trips to do courier work, especially with a view to establishing links with resistance fighters in [[Thuringia]], such as [[Theodor Neubauer]].<ref name="bda-koep" /> She also hid Franz Jacob in her flat for several months after he fled from [[Hamburg]].<ref name="gdw" />
==Arrest and Execution== Auer was arrested at her workplace on July 7, 1944 and was later tortured.<ref name="bda-koep" /> Along with [[Bruno Hämmerling]] and Franz Schmidt, she was sentenced to death at the [[Volksgerichtshof]]. Auer was hanged at [[Plötzensee Prison]] in Berlin on October 27, 1944.<ref name="gdw" />
== Legacy == [[File:Berlin-Bohnsdorf, Gedenkstein.jpg|thumb|right|Memorial in Berlin-Bohnsdorf for seven Bohnsdorfers killed resisting the nazi government. The caption reads: ''Brought to death, yet see: we live'']] There are streets named for Auer in Berlin, [[Leipzig]] and [[Jena]].<ref>[https://maps.google.com/maps?f=q&source=s_q&hl=en&geocode=&q=Judith-Auer-Stra%C3%9Fe,+Berlin,+Deutschland&sll=37.0625,-95.677068&sspn=39.507908,43.242187&ie=UTF8&hq=&hnear=Judith-Auer-Stra%C3%9Fe,+10369+Berlin,+Germany&t=h&z=16 Maplink to Judith-Auer-Straße, 10369 Berlin, Germany] Google Maps. Retrieved May 18, 2010</ref><ref>[https://maps.google.com/maps?f=q&source=s_q&hl=en&geocode=&q=Judith-Auer-Stra%C3%9Fe,+Leipzig,+Deutschland&sll=37.0625,-95.677068&sspn=39.507908,43.242187&ie=UTF8&hq=&hnear=Judith-Auer-Stra%C3%9Fe,+04317+Leipzig,+Sachsen,+Germany&t=h&z=16 Maplink to Judith-Auer-Straße, 04317 Leipzig, Germany] Google Maps. Retrieved May 18, 2010</ref><ref>[https://maps.google.com/maps?f=q&source=s_q&hl=en&geocode=&q=Judith-Auer-Stra%C3%9Fe,+Jena,+Deutschland&sll=37.0625,-95.677068&sspn=39.507908,43.242187&ie=UTF8&hq=&hnear=Judith-Auer-Stra%C3%9Fe,+Jena,+Th%C3%BCringen,+Germany&t=h&z=16 Maplink to Judith-Auer-Straße, Jena, Germany] Google Maps. Retrieved May 18, 2010</ref> In the former [[East Germany]], there are several public institutions named after her, as well.
== See also == * [[List of Germans who resisted Nazism]]
== Further reading == * "Judith Auer (1905 - 1944). Möge alles schmerzliche nicht umsonst gewesen sein", Ruth und Günther Hortzschansky, Trafo-Verlag Berlin, 2004
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == * {{DNB portal|129837989|TYP=}} * [http://bda-koepenick.de/verfolgte/judithauer1905.html Judith Auer geb. Vallenthin<!-- bot-generated title -->] at bda-koepenick.de * [http://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/Holocaust/Plotzensee.html Plötzensee Prison]
